Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Community and physiological ecology: Linking consumer homeostatic physiology and behavior to plant community dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
An important focus of ecology is understanding how the interplay between the environment and organisms shape ecosystems. For example, some studies have explored how changes in temperature and rainfall influence the types of animals and plants found within an area. Other studies have explored how organisms may shape their environment by building structures, or changing the chemistry or rate of nutrient processing within an environment. This study will directly link how environmental changes may influence broader ecological patterns through their effects on the physiology of animals. More specifically, this study examines how changes in the environment directly influence the internal physiology of small grassland rodents and how this physiological stress influences their foraging behavior which in turn influences the types of plants found in their habitats. New technologies will be employed to record and manipulate the internal stress levels experienced by rodents in the field and to track how this stress influences their movement, foraging and feeding patterns. This research is important in developing a general understanding of how organism physiology and behavior scale up to shape ecosystem properties. This study will also inform conservation efforts by allowing land managers to develop strategies that may reduce the negative effects of environmental change on the physiology of animals. This project will support the research training of undergraduate and graduate students and will provide opportunities for K-12 students and teachers.

The integration of animal homeostatic function into the field of ecology is essential for characterizing and forecasting the responses of communities to changing environmental conditions. Changes in the homeostatic function of animals may, for example, play an important role in structuring the form and function of ecosystems through shifts in animal physiology and behavior that influence predator-prey interactions, levels of competition and rates of nutrient cycling. Capitalizing on recent advances in radio-telemetry and physiological manipulation techniques, this study will experimentally alter the stress hormone and water physiology of granivorous kangaroo rats to track associated shifts in their foraging behavior and habitat use. By applying stable isotopes to flowering plants commonly consumed by these rodents, this study will close the loop between the physiological response of consumers to environmental stressors and its potential to alter seed dispersal and germination patterns. Integration of these disparate approaches will demonstrate a new community (physiological) ecology framework that may shift long-held research paradigms. This ecological framework will provide new opportunities for researchers to explore and test how diverse homeostatic processes (e.g. thermoregulation, ecoimmunology, and nutrient stoichiometry) mediate community function and structure across a variety of ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proof-of-concept EAGER project sought to combine cutting-edge telemetry technologies with physiological manipulations to probe classical ecological concepts. Indirect effects of animal physiology on ecological and trophic interactions have rarely been considered when exploring long-term impacts of environmental change for ecological communities. Animal physiology, however, mediates consumer behavioral responses and interactions with their environment. The lack of integration of physiology with classical ecology likely stems from technological hurdles that have hampered tracking animals and their interactions in high resolution. In order to begin filling these knowledge gaps, this project tested several novel tracking technologies and coupled physiological manipulations on rodents in a desert community, which is a model system for exploring animal and ecological interactions.

One approach tracked the long-term effects of corticosterone hormone on thermoregulation, behavioral, and ecological interactions. Temperature-sensitive dataloggers and silicone-hormone treatments were implanted in a population of banner-tailed kangaroo rats on the Sevilleta LTER in New Mexico. The dataloggers tracked changes in thermoregulation and behavior across five months. The silicone implants containing corticosterone hormones (or blanks for controls) were injected to mimic mildly elevated physiological stress that animals experience in response to environmental stressors. For mammals that regulate body temperature (i.e. endotherms), thermoregulation is very energetically expensive. Thus understanding shifts in either behavior or thermoregulatory patterns in response to environmental stressors could provide insight into how animals mitigate changing ecological conditions. Results from this study demonstrated a change in thermoregulatory precision that balanced reductions in foraging activity and energy intake with behavioral responses to shifting patterns of predator threat. This test also demonstrated that manipulation of hormonal factors mediating physiological responses to stressors strengthened the effect of background ecological patterns, which aided in disentangling often masked ecological interactions.

This project also tested a novel digital telemetry system marketed as capable of tracking small animals with 1-5 m resolution, thereby potentially allowing for tracking and linking consumer responses and ecological interactions to their physiological state. This first of its kind telemetry system was installed on a 1 km^2 grid of desert grassland at the Sevilleta LTER in New Mexico that contained another high-density population of kangaroo rats. Battery powered radio transmitter collars were placed on 124 banner-tailed kangaroo rats over two summers. While most telemetry systems are used to track animals over large areas, the aim of the system used in this project was to test the potential for tracking small mammals with small territories (<100m^2) in high resolution. This project also tested the feasibility and value of using trilateration (based on signal strength) instead of commonly used triangulation (based on signal direction) to estimate animal location. Enormous amounts of locality data were collected by the system that required a novel data analysis approach, developed by the PIs. However, several shortcomings of the system and trilateration approach were revealed by this analysis. First, critical failures of the collars and system reduced the time period of collected data to weeks, not the expected 3-6 months. Second, signal strength from the collars was substantially less than expected, and the relationship between signal strength and distance to receivers is non-linear, which meant the vast majority of signal “beeps” could not be localized by trilateration. Finally, for those signals that could be estimated, significant and often biased error, on the order of 10-200 meters, was introduced by the system design. Ultimately, this test suggests that advances to current telemetry technologies are still required for high resolution tracking of small terrestrial animals.

These experiments have inspired continued research exploring the long-term relationships between physiological mediation of behavioral and ecological interactions. The continued research includes retrospective analyses of animal physiological mediation of shifting climate and resource regimes, as well as a review of the phylogenetics of mammalian glucocorticoid patterns.

This project also had significant broader impacts on student education, training, and community outreach.  Two graduate students (MS) from underrepresented groups in science (one woman, and one Latin-American) were supported by this grant. An undergraduate student who assisted with the project was also inspired to pursue a MS degree in animal physiological ecology. These students also used their research in community outreach endeavors to teach local K12 students about animal ecology through the SIUC GRASS (Graduate Research Assistants Supporting Science) program.
